Easy to use

By preferring code over configuration, gulp keeps things simple and makes complex tasks manageable.

Efficient

Using the power of node streams, gulp gives you fast builds that don't write intermediary files to disk.

High Quality

By enforcing strict plugin guidelines, we ensure that plugins stay simple and work as expected.

Easy to Learn

Using node best practices and maintaining a minimal API surface, your build works exactly as you would imagine.

Since a gulpfile is a normal node application, it will start with requiring any plugins or modules you want to use.

  var gulp = require('gulp');

  var uglify = require('gulp-uglify');
  var coffee = require('gulp-coffee');
  var concat = require('gulp-concat');
  var imagemin = require('gulp-imagemin');

The next portion of a gulpfile is typically the definition of globs to be used in tasks. Keeping your globs in one place helps keep things DRY.

var paths = {
scripts: [
'client/js/**/*.coffee',
'!client/external/**/*.coffee'
],
images: 'client/img/**/*'
};

In gulp, we think of things as pipelines. Instead of making a task for each transform, we group based on file types.

In this example, we create a pipeline for scripts that compiles, minifies, and concatenates them before writing to a folder.

Using gulp-sourcemaps, we are able to maintain transformation history throughout the entire pipeline.

gulp.task('scripts', function () {
return gulp.src(paths.scripts, {sourcemaps: true})
.pipe(coffee())
.pipe(uglify())
.pipe(concat('all.min.js'))
.pipe(gulp.dest('build/js'));
});

requires n shit

gulp.task('images', function () {
return gulp.src(paths.images)
.pipe(imagemin({
optimizationLevel: 5
}))
.pipe(gulp.dest('build/img'));
});

requires n shit

gulp.task('watch', function () {
gulp.watch(paths.scripts, ['scripts']);
gulp.watch(paths.images, ['images']);
});

requires n shit

gulp.task('default', [
'scripts',
'images',
'watch'
]);
